newsitem.title: USA: U.S. September retail sales up on autos surge.
newsitem.headline: U.S. September retail sales up on autos surge.

text.p: Sales at retail stores posted a surprisingly strong rise in September, the Commerce Department said on Friday, largely because of a surge in business for new-car dealers.
Total retail sales increased last month by 0.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $205.7 billion after a steeply revised 0.2 percent decline in August sales.

But excluding automobile business, September retail sales were up a more modest 0.4 percent. That followed a revised 0.5 percent August drop that was the biggest decline since a 0.6 percent fall in October last year.
The overall 0.7 percent increase in September retail sales was well above Wall Street economists' forecasts for an 0.2 percent gain.
During September dealer sales of new cars rose 1.7 percent to $50.8 billion after a revised 0.5 percent August increase that previously was reported as only a 0.1 percent rise.

Analysts said beforehand that the department's survey of auto dealers had undercounted sales in August and likely would require a large revision. New cars account for about one-fifth of total retail sales, so swings in demand or problems in counting sales strongly affect the overall monthly figures.
Sales by general merchandise stores rose 0.3 percent to $26 billion after a 0.8 percent rise in August. At apparel stores, sales of clothing fell 0.1 percent after falling 0.5 percent in August.

Overall sales of durable goods, which includes cars and other long-lasting items, rose 0.9 percent in September after a 0.1 percent decline in August. Sales of non-durables like food and clothing increased 0.6 percent last month after falling 0.3 percent in August.
August sales previously were reported rising 0.2 percent but that was sharply revised to a show a 0.2 percent decline.
Sales of building materials increased 0.1 percent last month to $11.1 billion after dropping 2.2 percent in August.
Sales by food stores rose 1.2 percent to $35.6 billion last month following a 0.5 percent August drop.
Gasoline service station sales increased 0.6 percent to $13 billion after dropping 0.8 percent in August.
